newsitem.title: USA: BHP COPPER SPENDING IN PERU SEEN AT TINTAYA OXIDE.
newsitem.headline: BHP COPPER SPENDING IN PERU SEEN AT TINTAYA OXIDE.

text.p: A $150 million investment by BHP Minerals, a unit of Broken Hill Proprietary Co (BHP) of Australia, on a copper plant in Peru, as announced by the Peruvian government, is most likely an oxide-leaching project at the Tintaya mine, according to a BHP spokesman in the U.S.

Tintaya, which currently produces 143,709 tonnes of copper contained in concentrate annually, completed a feasibility study on an oxide project and accompanying solvent extraction-electrowinning plant at the mine in May, although the company hasn't issued any projected capital expenditures or operating figures to date.
"The Tintaya oxide project is furthest along its development," a spokesman said. "I assume that's what (the Peruvian government) is refering to." He declined to be more specific.
BHP is also drilling at the Coroccohuayco project 8 kilometres south of Tintaya. A pre-feasibility study is expected by the end of October 1997.

The government announced in an official daily publication that BHP would invest $150 million on a new copper plant in Peru. Company executives are currently meeting with government officials, the spokesman confirmed.
((Derek J. Caney, New York Commodity Desk, 212-859-1646))
